body:
Hello,

If it's okay with you, I would like to take a stab at this one. Can you assign it to me please?

Thanks,

Ben.
@BenTels happy to do that after we review the issue and how to address it.

@joel-costigliola 

> happy to do that after we review the issue and how to address it.

FYI: 

I've already been looking at the containsKey() case. I traced it back to the implementation of java.util.Map.containsKey() on the unmodifiable map that you get in case of f.e. the of() method. This is one that does not allow null keys, so it assumes internally that the key you are checking for is not null and throws an NPE if it is. Which, fair enough, is allowed under the spec of containsKey().

My first idea here is to wrap the existing call to containsKey() in a try/catch block, catch the NPE, check that the key being searched for is indeed null (so we know more or less for sure we are in the case described in the spec) and then just add null to the notfound set being filled in the existing code.

See org.assertj.core.internal.Maps, line 386.

@BenTels your proposal looks good from my point of view. Would you mind submitting a draft PR that addresses only one assertion (e.g., `containsKey`), so that we can agree on the overall pattern?

As the AssertJ code is Java 8 based, we cannot have test cases with `Map.of`, but you could use another `Map` implementation that does not accept `null` keys or values, like `ConcurrentHashMap`.

issue.title: Issue 2379 map assert throws npe on null key and value

labels.name: hacktoberfest-accepted
labels.description: We might not merge this PR before Nov 1st, but we acknowledge it as an Hacktoberfest contribution

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
#### Check List:
* Fixes #2379 (partially)
* Unit tests : YES 
* Javadoc with a code example (on API only) : NA
* PR meets the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/assertj/assertj-core/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) : Think so...

Following the [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/assertj/assertj-core/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) will make it easier for us to review and accept your PR.

This is a draft PR as requested by @scordio .

This fixes the NPE thrown when asserting containsKey(null) and doesNotContainKey(null) on certain map implementations that do not allow null keys.

Note: I am hoping that in fixing the *Value(null) side of it a pattern will emerge that will allow me to refactor the try/catch constructions into something neater...

body:
@scordio 

> Would you mind submitting a draft PR that addresses only one assertion (e.g., `containsKey`), so that we can agree on the overall pattern?

Only one....? Oops.... Would you settle for two? :grinning: 

See #2382 .

> As the AssertJ code is Java 8 based, we cannot have test cases with `Map.of`, but you could use another `Map` implementation that does not accept `null` keys or values, like `ConcurrentHashMap`.

Yes, I ran into that problem and created an implementation of Map that has part of the same implementation as Map1 to simulate the problem. I've added a test case for ConcurrentHashMap as well, but I will leave my own in place because that is guaranteed not to change beyond the control of the project.

Ben.
Anybody know what is up with pitest?

Not sure what went wrong there, I'll raise an issue with the project to ask for help. You can ignore it, of course.

There is actually a `java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space` error. Some tuning is probably needed.

Okay, I will ignore it for now. Thanks.

I've got the rest of the issue ready, but will keep it on hold until I hear what you guys think of what I've got so far.
PR now updated as @scordio has accepted it. Re #[2382](https://github.com/assertj/assertj-core/pull/2382#issuecomment-949707556).

issue.title: `containsExactly` does not work properly with maps not using equals to compare keys

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM
